title.value: MixupE: Understanding and Improving Mixup from Directional Derivative Perspective
title.justification: This is the title of the research paper.
title.quote: MixupE: Understanding and Improving Mixup from Directional Derivative Perspective

extractions.description: The paper introduces MixupE, an enhancement to the Mixup data augmentation technique. The authors analyze Mixup from a directional derivative perspective and propose MixupE, which theoretically and empirically improves generalization performance across various datasets and architectures.

type.justification: The paper proposes a new method (MixupE) and demonstrates its effectiveness through various experiments on multiple datasets and architectures.
type.quote: To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we conduct experiments across various domains such as images, tabular data, speech, and graphs.

name.justification: The primary research field of the paper is Machine Learning, focusing on improvements to the Mixup data augmentation technique for better generalization in neural networks.
name.quote: Mixup is a popular data augmentation technique for training deep neural networks where additional samples are generated by linearly interpolating pairs of inputs and their labels.

name.justification: The paper focuses on improving the Mixup data augmentation technique by proposing an enhanced version called MixupE.
name.quote: Mixup is a popular data augmentation technique for training deep neural networks where additional samples are generated by linearly interpolating pairs of inputs and their labels.

name.justification: The proposed MixupE is designed to enhance the implicit regularization effects of Mixup, making it a study of regularization techniques as well.
name.quote: In this paper, we show that Mixup is equivalent to implicitly adding infinitely many regularization terms on the directional derivatives of all orders instead of a complex second-order form.

name.justification: MixupE is the main model proposed and contributed by this paper. It is an enhancement of the Mixup technique.
name.quote: Based on this novel insight, this paper proposes to explicitly enhance the implicit regularization effect of Mixup on the directional derivatives. Instead of computing all infinite regularization terms, we efficiently approximate the dominant term using accessible results during each forward propagation, ensuring computational efficiency. We name this method as MixupE (Mixup Enhanced).

is_contributed.justification: MixupE is a new method introduced by the authors as an improvement over the existing Mixup technique.
is_contributed.quote: Based on this novel insight, this paper proposes to explicitly enhance the implicit regularization effect of Mixup on the directional derivatives. Instead of computing all infinite regularization terms, we efficiently approximate the dominant term using accessible results during each forward propagation, ensuring computational efficiency. We name this method as MixupE (Mixup Enhanced).

is_executed.justification: The paper includes experiments demonstrating the implementation and effectiveness of MixupE across various datasets and architectures.
is_executed.quote: To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we conduct experiments across various domains such as images, tabular data, speech, and graphs.

is_compared.justification: MixupE is compared with other models such as ERM and Mixup in various experiments to demonstrate improvement in performance.
is_compared.quote: Empirically, MixupE outperforms Mixup on several datasets, such as image, tabular, and speech datasets, trained with various networks. The improvement in test error is more significant for networks with larger capacities.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Mixup technique, which MixupE aims to improve, is originally proposed and detailed in the paper titled 'mixup: Beyond empirical risk minimization'.
referenced_paper_title.quote: To address this limitation of ERM, Mixup [Zhang et al., 2018] has recently been proposed as an alternative training principle.

name.justification: Mixup is a baseline model that the proposed MixupE aims to improve upon. It is referenced and used for comparison in this paper.
name.quote: To address this limitation of ERM, Mixup [Zhang et al., 2018] has recently been proposed as an alternative training principle.

is_contributed.justification: Mixup is not contributed by this paper; it is an existing technique that the authors aim to improve.
is_contributed.quote: Mixup [Zhang et al., 2018] creates synthetic training samples by linear interpolation in the input vectors and their corresponding labels.

is_executed.justification: The paper includes experiments that execute the Mixup model for comparison with the proposed MixupE.
is_executed.quote: To validate that the method is not overly sensitive to the newly introduced hyperparameter η, we conducted experiments for MixupE with the value of η ∈ {0.0001, 0.001, 0.01, 0.1} with Preactresnet50 architecture and the CIFAR-100 dataset.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the performance of Mixup with MixupE through various experiments to highlight improvements.
is_compared.quote: We show results for the CIFAR-10 (Table 1a), CIFAR-100 (Table 1b), SVHN (Table 2a), and Tiny-ImageNet (Table 2b) datasets. We see that MixupE consistently outperforms baseline methods ERM and Mixup across all the datasets and architectures.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Mixup technique is originally proposed in the paper titled 'mixup: Beyond empirical risk minimization'.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Mixup [Zhang et al., 2018] creates synthetic training samples by linear interpolation in the input vectors and their corresponding labels.

name.justification: The CIFAR-10 dataset is used for evaluating the performance of the proposed MixupE method.
name.quote: We show results for the CIFAR-10 (Table 1a), CIFAR-100 (Table 1b), SVHN (Table 2a), and Tiny-ImageNet (Table 2b) datasets.

name.quote: We show results for the CIFAR-10 (Table 1a), CIFAR-100 (Table 1b), SVHN (Table 2a), and Tiny-ImageNet (Table 2b) datasets.

name.justification: The UCI datasets are used for the evaluation of MixupE in experiments involving tabular data.
name.quote: For small-scale image datasets, we consider the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, SVHN, and Tiny-ImageNet. We run our experiments using a variety of architectures, including PreActResNet18, PreActResNet34, PreActResNet50, PreActResNet101 [He et al., 2016], and Wide-Resnet-28-10 [Zagoruyko and Komodakis, 2016].

referenced_paper_title.justification: The UCI datasets are hosted in the 'UCI Machine Learning Repository'.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We consider a number of tabular environments drawn from the UCI dataset [Lichman et al., 2013], namely Arrhythmia, Letter, Balance-scale, Mfeat-factors, Mfeat-fourier, Mfeat-karhunen, Mfeat-morphological, Mfeat-zernike, CMC, Optdigits, Pendigits, Iris, Mnist_784, Abalone and Volkert.

name.justification: Pytorch is mentioned as the implementation framework for running the experiments in the discussed domains.
name.quote: The code is available at https://github.com/oneHuster/MixupE.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Pytorch library is detailed in the paper 'Automatic Differentiation in PyTorch'.
